title-group.article-title: Agro-industrial alluvium in the Swale catchment, northern England, as an event marker for the Anthropocene

author-notes.corresp: Simon A Foulds, Centre for Catchment and Coastal Research and River Basin Dynamics and Hydrology Research Group, Institute of Geography & Earth Sciences, Aberystwyth University, Llandinam Building, Penglais Campus, Aberystwyth SY23 3DB, UK. Email: sif3@aber.ac.uk

abstract.p: Physically and chemically distinctive late-Prehistoric and historical age alluvial deposits are characteristic of many upland and lowland river systems in the UK. Despite their widespread distribution, there have been few attempts to construct robust chronologies or to identify environmental factors that governed their formation. The Swale catchment in northern England is typical in this respect, with large areas of its valley floor covered by sedimentologically distinctive laminated sands and silts, enriched in organic material and Pb, and underlain by uncontaminated and structureless silts. Using 14C dating, chemostratigraphy, lichenometry and historical maps, a catchment-wide change in sedimentation style has been dated to between the mid 18th and early 19th centuries ad. Several causative factors were responsible for this change in sedimentation style and include the initiation of large-scale, intensive lead mining from the latter half of the 18th century onwards, embankment construction in the lowlands and historical peat erosion in the uplands. Transformation of the Swale floodplain also reflects longer-term land-use and climate change. In particular, deforestation of headwater tributaries by monastic grazing practices in the High Middle Ages (ad 1000–1300) led to a period of fine-grained sedimentation in upland catchments, as well as priming hillslopes for erosion and widespread channel network incision and increased fine sediment flux during the climatic downturn of the ‘Little Ice Age’. Sediment facies of a similar nature have been widely recorded in other northern English river catchments and represent a regional land use–climate signal characteristic of the Anthropocene. We introduce the term ‘agro-industrial alluvium’ to describe these types of deposit. They have similarities to post-settlement alluvium in North America and Australia, where historical land-use change had a similar impact on valley floor sedimentology.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Physically and chemically distinctive late-Prehistoric and historical age alluvial deposits that are believed to be associated with farming and base-metal mining and processing are characteristic of many upland and lowland river systems in the UK. Typically, these deposits are fine-grained and tend to form upstanding river terraces (Hooke et al., 1990; Johnstone, 2004; Macklin and Lewin, 1986; Macklin et al., 1991), or distinctive sediment blankets that cap coarser, earlier channel deposits (Brown, 2009; Brown and Barber, 1985; Brown and Keough, 1992; Brown et al., 1994; Buckland and Sandler, 1985; Foster et al., 2000; Hazelden and Jarvis, 1979; Robinson and Lambrick, 1984; Samuels and Buckland, 1978). Diagnostic sedimentological features include colour (Howard, 2005; Howard et al., 2000; Shotton, 1978), sedimentation style (Passmore and Macklin, 1994; Richards, 1981; Richards et al., 1986; Thorp and Gallagher, 1999) and elevated metal concentrations (Cu, Pb, Sn and Zn). High metal contaminant levels are particularly associated with historical base-metal mining in northern England (Hudson-Edwards et al., 1999a, 1999b; Macklin and Lewin, 1989; Macklin et al., 1994; Passmore and Macklin, 1994; Taylor et al., 2000) and Wales (Lewin et al., 1983; Macklin and Lewin, 1986), and tin mining in southwest England (Thorndycraft et al., 2004).

Although alluvium associated with anthropogenic activity has been reported in many parts of the UK (see review by Foulds and Macklin, 2006), surprisingly few attempts have been made to construct high-resolution chronologies for these deposits or elucidate the factors that controlled their formation. Meta-analysis of the UK Holocene fluvial record has shown that the last 1000 years been characterised by increased floodplain sedimentation rates and that many of these deposits date to this period (Johnstone et al., 2006; Macklin and Lewin, 2003; Macklin et al., 2005, 2010, 2012). They usually have a strong connection with land-use change from the late-Saxon–Medieval periods (9th century ad) (Brown, 2009), and were especially associated with farming activity during the agricultural revolution of the High Middle Ages (11th–14th centuries ad) (Macklin et al., 2010).

The Swale catchment in northern England is characterised by distinctive laminated sandy and organic-rich silt floodplain sediments (Figure 1a–c) that are contaminated, to varying degrees, with Pb and Zn (Dennis et al., 2009; Macklin et al., 1994; Sedgwick, 1998). We introduce the term ‘agro-industrial alluvium’ to describe these deposits and suggest they represent an event marker for stratigraphically identifying the Anthropocene (cf. Zalasiewicz et al., 2011) in riverine environments. They have been identified throughout the Yorkshire Ouse catchment (Howard et al., 2000; Hudson-Edwards et al., 1999a, 1999b; Macklin et al., 2000), of which the River Swale is a major tributary, and they are linked to accelerated fine sediment delivery resulting from agriculture, mining and associated processing activities dating from the Medieval period onwards. The principal aim of this paper is to elucidate the precise age and genesis of these deposits and to determine what environmental factors caused the change of sedimentation style within the Swale catchment.

sec.title: Study catchment
sec.p: The River Swale is the northernmost tributary of the Yorkshire Ouse, flowing for c. 118 km in an easterly/southeasterly direction before joining the River Ure at Myton (Figure 2). Total catchment area is approximately 1500 km2, covering a range of environments from peat-covered uplands to fertile agricultural land in the lowlands. The upland part of the catchment is characterised by alternating layers of limestone, shale and sandstone, which are known as the Carboniferous Yoredale Series and form the upper part of the Askrigg Block (Pounder, 1989). Exposures of these rocks can be seen in glacially eroded valleys of upper Swaledale, along with other glacial landforms of the Dimlington Stadial, such as moraines, drumlins and meltwater channels (Raistrick, 1926; Rose, 1980). Substrate in the lowlands is dominated by Permian–Triassic rocks (mudstones, sandstones and limestones) and the entire catchment is overlain by Late Pleistocene glacial and glacio-fluvial deposits.

caption.p: Location map of the Swale catchment showing study reaches and other sites discussed in the text.

sec.p: Upland and piedmont reaches of the River Swale have relatively steep channel gradients (0.0093 and 0.0031 m/m, respectively), and show, in the form of river terraces, evidence of repeated aggradation-incision phases during the Holocene, which has produced valley floor relief in the order of 5–6 m (Figures 3 and 6). At tributary–trunk stream confluence zones in the upland part of the Swale catchment (Figures 4 and 5), alluvial fans impinge on the main channel, reducing channel gradients upstream (0.0037 and 0.0023 m/m, respectively), resulting in sedimentation and lateral reworking of older material. Lowland reaches have lower gradients (0.0010–0.0003 m/m) and have been characterised by progressive vertical accretion during the Holocene, producing valley floor relief of c. 2 m, although local relief can be higher in inter-flood embankment zone (Figure 7).

caption.p: Valley floor geomorphology at Isles Bridge.

sec.p: Floods in the Yorkshire Ouse catchment tend to be generated by westerly and cyclonic weather patterns (Longfield and Macklin, 1999). The largest events are associated with rain-on-snow conditions (Macklin and Rumsby, 2007; Merrett and Macklin, 1999) and thunderstorms during the summer months (Newson and Macklin, 1990). Long-term river discharge data are limited in the Swale catchment, but a good record exists for Crakehill in the lowlands. At this location, based on water years from 1957 to 2005, mean annual and mean annual maximum discharge are 20.1 m3/s and 158.4 m3/s, respectively.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Geomorphological mapping in the Swale catchment was combined with sedimentological–geochemical analysis of historical age alluvial deposits that were dated using a range of techniques. Catchment land-use history was reconstructed using palynological, archaeological and documentary evidence (Foulds, 2008). These data were combined with climate proxies for the north of England to provide an environmental context within which to interpret the fluvial record.

sec.title: Geomorphological mapping
sec.p: Colour aerial photographs were used to map the Swale valley floor. Ordnance Survey (OS) Landline and contour data were overlaid, allowing accurate definition of geomorphological features in relation to slope and fixed reference points (field boundaries, buildings and roads). Features identified using air photographs were then verified in the field and fine-tuned using LiDAR data (cf. Jones et al., 2007). Where LiDAR data were not available, primary elevation data were generated through field survey with a Trimble differential GPS system. To elucidate patterns and the timing of historical planform channel change in the Swale system, OS maps (1854–1992) and aerial photographs (flown in 2000) were used. Typically, digitization of first and second edition OS maps gives accuracy of ± 2 m, and changes in excess of 5 m are likely to reflect genuine channel change, rather than data handling errors (Gurnell et al., 1994; Winterbottom, 2000). Cartographic sources (OS and local estate maps) were also used to date the construction of channel embankments in lowland reaches of the Swale catchment.

sec.title: Sedimentological analysis
sec.p: Grain-size analysis of floodplain sequences provides a method of identifying potential sediment sources (Sutherland, 1991), depositional conditions (Blott et al., 2004) and changes in sedimentology that may relate to geomorphologically significant changes in river activity (Macklin and Lewin, 2003). With this in mind, sediment samples (n = 23) were collected from subsurface cores and exposed bank sections, as well as from potential sediment sources in the catchment, including hillslope drift deposits and mine spoil tips in the upper catchment. Grain-size was determined using a combination of wet (<63 µm) and dry (2000–63 µm) sieving (Whalley, 1990), and grain-size statistics were calculated following the methods of Folk and Ward (1957). To determine the organic content of sediment samples, loss-on-ignition analysis was undertaken using a protocol of 4 h at 550°C (Heiri et al., 2001).

sec.title: Geochemical analysis
sec.p: Alluvium in the Swale catchment is characterised by elevated concentrations of various elements, particularly Pb, resulting from historical mining activity (Dennis et al., 2003, 2009; Macklin et al., 1994). To identify sedimentological changes that coincide with geochemical variations, particularly large-scale 18th and 19th century lead mining activity, sediment samples were analysed using XRF and ICP-MS techniques. An Itrax XRF core scanner was used to analyse split sediment cores at very high resolution, giving characterization of down-core geochemical data in unprecedented detail for historical age alluvium in northern England. X-rays used to irradiate samples were generated from a 3 kW Mo (molybdenum) tube energy source (Croudance et al., 2006; Rothwell et al., 2006) using an exposure time of 30 s. A step size of 0.5 µm was selected to characterise the geochemical variation of cores taken from the Swale catchment, which is comparable with some of the finest sedimentary structures in the cores examined. Sediment samples from exposed bank sections were prepared and digested for ICP-MS analysis following the method of Dennis et al. (2003). Following digestion, solutions were analysed using an Elemental Plasma Quad ICP20P ICP-MS. Typically, this technique gives measures of concentration (mg/kg) with precision and accuracy of ≤ 5% (Dennis et al., 2003). ICP-MS data, along with previously published work (Dennis et al., 2009; Macklin et al., 1994), have been used to establish Pb concentrations in sediment units. High resolution XRF scan Pb data (counts) has been used to identify the ‘take-off’ in sediment associated Pb due to mining and has been compared with upstream mining production records to give chemostratigraphic age estimates (Macklin, 1985). Documentary records of mining production (Dunham and Wilson, 1985; Fieldhouse and Jennings, 1978) were used to date periods of historical mining. Mine output records for Swaledale are amongst the most complete in the UK (Dennis, 2005) and extend back to the 17th century.

sec.title: Dating control
sec.p: Six new radiocarbon dates were obtained in this study, collected from percussion coring and river bank sections. This supplemented 14 other radiocarbon dates collected during previous research in the Swale catchment, both published (Brewer et al., 2005; Taylor and Macklin, 1997; Taylor et al., 2000) and unpublished (Dennis and Macklin; Howard and Macklin), giving a total of 20 dates. Full details of these, including the type of material analysed (wood, charcoal or bone) and method (radiometric or AMS) are given in Table 1. All dates have been calibrated (2 σ) using Oxcal version 4 (Reimer et al., 2004). Multiple dates from the same cores and bank sections are in depth-chronological order, which implies the material dated is reliable. However, use of radiocarbon to date recent sediments is problematic because of the wide range of possible calibrated dates. For this reason we have used several other dating methods (chemostratigraphy, lichenometry and cartographic analysis) to determine the age of agro-industrial sediments.

caption.p: Uncalibrated and calibrated (2σ) radiocarbon dates from the Swale catchment. Dates have been calibrated using Oxcal. version 4.0 (Reimer et al., 2004).

sec.p: Within some upland reaches of the Swale catchment there is a clear morphostratigraphic relationship between coarse-grained cobble/boulder units (dated using lichenometry) and agro-industrial alluvium. Where historical river channels have been abandoned through avulsion, agro-industrial alluvium can be found within palaeochannels deposited by overbank flows after channel abandonment. By dating the cobble and boulder flood deposits, this gives maximum age estimates for sedimentation of agro-industrial alluvium at these sites. The growth rate of Rhizocarpon geographicum in the Yorkshire Dales (Merrett and Macklin, 1999) was used in this study. Lichen specimens were measured by recording the long axis of the five largest specimens using stainless steel callipers, which are accurate to c. ± 1 mm. The average lichen diameter was then calculated and converted to an age estimate using a linear regression derived growth rate of 0.36 mm/yr (Merrett and Macklin, 1999). Merrett (2001) calculated a 5 yr lag for colonisation of tombstones.

sec.title: Sedimentology of agro-industrial alluvium
sec.p: Agro-industrial alluvium is found at all reaches and is characterised by horizontally laminated fine sands, silts and organic-rich peaty material (Figures 1a, 1b, 1c, 8, 9 and 10). This unit is contaminated with Pb (typically 300–≥10,000 mg/kg) (Figure 10b; Dennis et al., 2009; Macklin et al., 1994). Other diagnostic features include a lack of bioturbation, indicative of relatively rapid sedimentation (Johnson et al., 1980), and inclusion of human artefacts, including early-modern/modern (c. 1750 onwards) pottery fragments found at Brompton. At upland (Hoggarths, Muker, Isles Bridge, How Hill, Reeth and Arkle Beck) and piedmont (Brompton) reaches these deposits form a 200–300 m wide swathe (Figures 3–6) c. 0.5–2.0 m in thickness (Figures 1, 8, 9 and 12) and extend up to 2 m above modern low-water levels. In lowland parts of the Swale catchment agro-industrial alluvium is more extensive, covering up to 500 m (Figure 7) or more of the valley floor and in places between 3 and 4 m thick (Figure 9d). It is underlain by a silty unit (Figure 9a, c and e) with abundant wood, or gravel and cobbles (Figure 8g). The change to agro-industrial alluvium is abrupt in all sections and cores. Fine-grained units in older Holocene terraces are typically composed of structureless sands and silts, which have Pb levels close to or below background concentrations (<500 mg/kg) (Dennis et al., 2009; Macklin et al., 1994). However, even on Holocene-age terraces up to 3–4 m above the modern river channel surficial sediment samples (c. 0–15 cm depth) have elevated Pb concentrations, indicating that large floods have occasionally overtopped these units (Brewer et al., 2005; Dennis et al., 2009).

sec.p: Although agro-industrial and older Holocene floodplain sediments are sedimentologically and geochemically different, they have similar grain-size properties (Figure 11; Table 2). Colluvium and older Holocene-age fluvial deposits have comparable mean grain-sizes (fine to very fine sand, Table 2), being dominated by silts (35% and 36%), fine sands (20% and 29%) and appreciable amounts of clay (7% and 9%). Agro-industrial alluvium is subtly different from older Holocene alluvium and colluvium, with relatively small amounts of coarse/very coarse sand (1%), less silt (23%) and clay (3%) and significantly more fine sand (64%) (Figure 11). Medieval/post-Medieval age alluvium is dominated by silt (47%), whereas modern overbank flood sediments are much coarser than their older Holocene counterparts.

sec.title: Geochronology
sec.p: In upland reaches of the Swale catchment, radiocarbon assays (Tables 1 and 3) indicate that sedimentation of the structureless silty unit that underlies agro-industrial alluvium began in the 12th to 13th centuries ad at Reeth (cal. ad 1190–1285). At How Hill, c. 1 km upstream of Isles Bridge, a date from the base of the same unit gave a comparable age (cal. ad 1040–1280). Because of the large calibrated age range of 14C dates younger than 300 BP (Table 3), it is not possible to be precise about when sedimentation of this unit ended and agro-industrial alluviation began at How Hill, Isles Bridge and Arkle Beck. However, at Reeth an unpublished date (Howard and Macklin, Table 1), located at the transition zone from unstructured sands and silts to agro-industrial alluvium, gave a date cal. ad 1470–1655. Despite these radiocarbon dating uncertainties, at both Reeth and Isles Bridge there was a clear break between sedimentation of Medieval silt alluvium and the onset of agro-industrial alluviation, as c. 0.75 m of structureless sands and silts separate the two units (Figure 9). In piedmont and lowland reaches of the River Swale the change to agro-industrial alluvium took place after cal. ad 1410–1620 at Brompton and after cal. ad 1485–1650 at Morton, very similar to the date at Reeth.

caption.p: Summary of radiocarbon (calibrated (2σ)) radiocarbon dates, lichen, chemostratigraphic and cartographic dating evidence used to constrain the age of agro-industrial alluvium in the Swale catchment.

sec.p: Radiocarbon dating of alluvium in the Swale catchment indicates two distinct periods of fine-grained sedimentation in the last 1000 years. The first, comprising clay-rich silt, began in the 11th to 13th centuries ad and ended sometime between the 15th and mid-17th centuries ad (Table 3). The second (agro-industrial alluvium) phase of sedimentation may have begun towards the end of the 15th century ad, or as late as the mid-17th century ad. Both Medieval and agro-industrial alluvial units are inset below mid- to late-Holocene river terraces that date to 2030–1775 cal. bc (3980–3725 cal. BP) and 2340–2040 cal. bc (4290–3990 cal. BP) at Hoggarths and Muker, and 890–550 cal. bc (2840–2500 cal. BP) at Brompton (Table 1). In the lower Swale catchment radiocarbon dating of floodplain sediments at Myton-on-Swale show there has been around 3.5 m of silty-sand sedimentation since ad 1025–1220 (925–735 cal. BP; Table 1).

In order to date the onset of agro-industrial alluviation more precisely, chemostratigraphic profiles of these deposits were linked to upstream mining records to provide high-resolution age estimates (Table 3). Figure 12 shows the variability of Pb with depth in relation to sedimentological units and Pb tonnage output from all mines upstream of the sampling location. Typically, agro-industrial alluvium is characterised by peak Pb concentrations that range from 800 to ≥ 10,000 mg/kg (Figure 10, Macklin et al., 1994). To gain a more detailed picture of sedimentological–geochemical relationships, an Itrax XRF core-scanner was used to produce continuous down-core geochemical data. There is a tendency for Pb counts to increase close to the abrupt change in sedimentology, typically at 0.5 m to 1.4 m at Isles Bridge and Reeth, respectively (Figure 12). Comparisons with upstream mining output records indicate dates of c. ad 1750–1780 for the onset of agro-industrial alluviation at these sites. At Morton the change is less clear owing to core retrieval problems associated with sandy units. Taken in conjunction with radiocarbon assays that bracket sedimentation of agro-industrial alluvium to the last 300–500 years, chemostratigraphy provides further chronological refinement, indicating likely dates for the onset of sedimentation between c. ad 1699 and 1817.

caption.p: Itrax XRF core scan results from (a) Isles Bridge, Reeth (b and c) and (d) Morton-on-Swale. (e), (f), (g) and (h) show Pb output from all mines upstream of the sampling location.

sec.p: Lichenometry was also used to explore age relationships between boulder berms in headwater tributaries formed during large flood events. In Gunnerside Gill, located between Muker and Isles Bridge (Figure 2), agro-industrial alluvium fills a alaeochannel that dissects a boulder-berm covered terrace. This feature was dated to ad 1822 ± 5 (Figure 1c) and is inset below a higher boulder flood unit, dated to ad 1814 ± 5. At this site an avulsion caused abandonment of the river channel after c. ad 1822, followed by alluviation with agro-industrial sediment thereafter and providing a maximum age of c. ad 1822 for this style of sedimentation at Gunnerside.

A similar temporal relationship was established at Muker, where a series of mid-channel bars associated with historical braiding were lichen dated to ad 1835 ± 5 (Figure 3). Historical maps show a single thread channel at this location in ad 1854, straightening to the river’s current position before ad 1914. The present Swale channel bed is incised c. 1.5 m below the historical braided planform and palaeochannels on this terrace are filled with fine-grained agro-industrial material that was deposited after c. ad 1835. Above this historical braided fill there is an older terrace unit, the upper 0.5 m of which is also capped by agro-industrial alluvium and must have been deposited before c. ad 1835. The floodplain at Muker, inset below the braided ad 1835 terrace, is also composed of similar agro-industrial alluvium, indicating that this style of sedimentation carried on after c. ad 1835.

Historical maps show that most, if not all of the embankments in the lower Swale downstream of the confluence with Bolton Beck (Figure 2), appear in their present form on first edition OS maps of ad 1854/1856. A late 18th century map of the River Swale at Kiplin, just upstream of Morton-on-Swale shows a series of embankments accompanied by the text ‘Grafs bank, made by Mr Crowe in 1791’. At Topcliffe (Figure 2), floodplain sediment cores retrieved from outside flood embankments revealed unstructured sands and silts, whereas channel bank exposures within the embanked zone showed well laminated agro-industrial alluvium. A similar pattern is evident Myton and indicates the deposition of agro-industrial alluvium took place after embankment construction in the late 18th century.

To summarise, calibrated radiocarbon show that the onset of agro-industrial alluvium occurred in the last 300–500 yr cal. BP. Chemostratigraphic age estimates are more precise and indicate that deposition began at c. ad 1700–1820, which agrees with cartographic evidence suggesting that deposition of agro-industrial alluvium began in the Swale catchment in the late 18th century. Figure 13 shows a summary of these data presented as a height–age diagram.

caption.p: Height–age diagram of agro-industrial alluvium in the Swale catchment. Cartographic age estimates reflect (1) the age (based on historical maps) of recent sand and gravel floodplain deposits that do not contain agro-industrial alluvium, and (2) known construction dates of floodplain embankments within which agro-industrial alluvium is found. Climate and land-use proxy data from northern England include: (1) cooler and/or wetter phases at May, North Yorkshire Moors (Chiverrell, 2001); (2) monastic land grants in upper Swaledale (Fieldhouse and Jennings, 1978); (3) clearance episodes on Ellerton Moor (Reeth) (Livett and Fleming, unpublished data, 1998), Swaledale; and (4) historical mining activity in Swaledale (Barker and White, 1992; Gill, 2001). The stippled bar corresponds to radiocarbon-dated bale smelting sites that were in use before the mid 18th century. The white bar indicates the start of large-scale mining in the mid 18th century; the black bar indicates the period of peak production (c. ad 1783 to c. ad 1886); (5) flood embankment construction in the Swale lowlands based on Kiplin estate map (original held at North Yorkshire County Records Office, Northallerton, North Yorkshire, UK).

sec.p: The spatial extent and volumes of agro-industrial alluvium storage in the River Swale study reaches are shown in Table 4. The greatest mass of agro-industrial alluvium is stored at Morton, with lower storage values at Brompton and Isles Bridge reflecting the geomorphology of these reaches where agro-industrial alluvium is constrained within a relatively narrow corridor inset below older terrace units. The greatest areal extent of agro-industrial alluvium as a proportion of the valley floor (96%) is found at Reeth. Given the high concentrations of Pb in agro-industrial alluvium, there is significant potential for remobilisation and dispersal of contaminants, particularly at Reeth and Morton, where the river channel is laterally active and bank erosion rates are high.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our investigations have shown that several factors led to the abrupt change in sedimentation style and deposition of agro-industrial alluvium in the Swale catchment. One of the most important was the initiation of large-scale, intensive lead mining. Although the impacts of metal mining can be seen from elemental lead concentrations in river sediments downstream as far as York from the Medieval period onwards (Hudson-Edwards et al., 1999a), it was not until the mid 18th century that large-scale and intensive exploitation began. Peak production occurred between ad 1783 and ad 1886, when 2000–7000 t/yr of ore were being extracted (Figure 12h). Up to 155,000 t of waste Pb from these mining processes has been stored in alluvial units throughout the Swale catchment (Dennis et al., 2009) and the change to agro-industrial alluvium corresponds closely with increased sediment Pb levels. As well as contributing significantly to increased fine sediment loads in the Swale catchment and wider Yorkshire Ouse system (Macklin et al., 2000), mining activity also caused river channel metamorphosis and the development of braiding in many headwater tributaries because of coarse-grained sediment supply and destruction of riparian vegetation because of pollution (cf. Lewin and Macklin, 1987). Fine-grained peaty silts that form a significant component of agro-industrial alluvium were sourced from mining waste ‘slimes’ (Lewin and Macklin, 1987) and historical peat erosion and gullying in the Pennine uplands (Bower, 1960; Tallis, 1965) from the late 18th century onwards (Tallis, 1997). Alluvial deposits very similar in nature to agro-industrial alluvium in the River Swale have been reported by Thorp and Gallagher (1999) in the Liffey catchment, Ireland. Its formation was linked primarily to peat erosion, although some units were enriched with mining waste. These deposits form the modern Liffey floodplain and date from cal. ad 1650–1800.

Changing farming practices were also important in ‘priming’ the catchment for instability and promoting the switch to agro-industrial alluvial sedimentation, especially deforestation of headwater tributaries. These systems govern sediment supply because they are usually directly coupled to river channels and steep terrain promotes erosion and transmission of sediment to river channels (Harvey, 2001; Hooke, 2003). Based on archaeological, documentary and palynological data, it appears that not until the High Middle Ages (c. ad 1000–1300) were steep and difficult to access headwater tributary catchments cleared of their woodland. This was primarily through monastic grazing practices (Donkin, 1969; McDonnell, 1992), when large tracts of the upper catchment were granted to Bridlington Priory and Rievaulx Abbey at the turn of the 12th century ad (Fieldhouse and Jennings, 1978). The last small vestiges of these ancient semi-natural woodlands can still be found in some of these valleys and Old English and Old Norse toponyms, indicative of woodland and clearings (Foulds, 2008; Gelling and Cole, 2000; Gledhill, 1995; McDonnell, 1992), suggest that these tributary woodlands were formerly much more extensive in early Medieval times.

Palynological evidence from a moorland site just south of Reeth shows a final phase of clearance at c. cal. ad 1095–1245 (Livett and Fleming, unpublished data, 1998), which ties in well with the timing of Monastic settlement and agricultural expansion. Elsewhere in Yorkshire, in the steep tributary valley of Skell Gill (c. 25 km south of Swaledale), tree and shrub pollen reached up to 80% at c. cal. ad 779–1160, followed by a marked clearance episode in the 12th–13th centuries and linked to land-use change (grazing) by the Cistercians (Tinsley, 1975), as well as deforestation related to timber extraction for lead smelting fuel. On the basis of 14C-dated floodplain units, Medieval alluviation associated with land-use change in the region appears to have been widespread in the Yorkshire Ouse and its tributaries (Howard et al., 2000; Macklin et al., 2000).

Medieval deforestation primed the Swale uplands for erosion but the trigger was climatic variability during the ‘Little Ice Age’. Regional climate proxies (Figure 13) pick out cooler and wetter conditions during the ‘Little Ice Age’ (Barber and Langdon, 2007; Chiverrell, 2001; Mauquoy et al., 2008) that correspond with periods of agro-industrial alluvial sedimentation in the Swale catchment. Wetter climatic conditions have been identified at May Moss, North Yorkshire Moors, at cal. ad 1400–1620 and cal. ad 1700–1800 (Chiverrell, 2001), at Walton Moss cal. ad 1710–1800 (Barber and Langdon, 2007) and c. cal. ad 1790 at Butterburn Flow (Cumbria) (Mauquoy et al., 2008). The climatic downturn of the ‘Little Ice Age’ led to an increased frequency and magnitude of extreme flooding in the British uplands after c. ad 1650 (Macklin and Rumsby, 2007; Macklin et al., 1992a, 1992b; Merrett and Macklin, 1999; Rumsby and Macklin, 1994, 1996). Fine material generated during these large floods led to the deposition of sandy splays across floodplains areas that are preserved as thick sand units in contemporary bank exposures of agro-industrial alluvium.

The combination of land-use change and climatic deterioration also had a significant impact on sediment transfer in the Swale catchment. The Swale valley floor at Isles Bridge and Reeth aggraded with the deposition of up to 2.0 m thick sheets of sand and peaty silt, whilst in the piedmont region of the Swale catchment, at Brompton (reach 8 on Figure 2), rates of lateral reworking were high, with 62% of the Holocene valley floor being formed after cal. ad 1320–1470. This is typical of piedmont locations fringing the UK uplands where channel slope and discharge are maximised (Lewin and Macklin, 2010). Given the timing of these geomorphological changes, a significant contribution to agro-industrial alluviation in the Swale catchment was likely to have been the erosion, transfer and deposition of sand and silt during large floods from the mid-17th century onwards (Merrett and Macklin, 1999) associated with widespread channel network incision in upland areas in the early part of the 19th century.

In the lower reaches of the Swale catchment, sediment eroded from upland and piedmont areas has been deposited between channel embankments built between the late 18th and mid 19th centuries, resulting in significant valley floor aggradation. At Morton-on-Swale (Figure 9d), c. 3.7 m of agro-industrial alluvium has been deposited since cal. ad 1485–1650, giving sedimentation rates of between c. 9 and 12 mm/yr. The association of sedimentologically distinctive alluvium deposited within flood embankments in the Swale catchment is similar to other European catchments (Ciszewski and Turner, 2009; Hesselink et al., 2003; Hudson et al., 2008; Macklin and Klimek, 1992). The construction of flood defences along the River Swale confined sedimentation within a much smaller floodplain and partially facilitated the formation of agro-industrial alluvium in the Swale lowlands.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Our research in the Swale catchment, northern England, demonstrates that significant changes in land use, particularly the effects of metal mining and construction of flood embankments over the last 200–300 years, have led to dramatic changes in the style and pattern of valley floor sedimentation, most notable of which has been the deposition of a distinctive fluvial unit that we term ‘agro-industrial alluvium’. Using a combination of geomorphological mapping and multiple geochronological techniques, the onset of this style of sedimentation has been dated to the mid 18th to early 19th centuries and is related to a combination of factors. Of particular importance was large-scale extraction and processing of base-metal ores from the mid 18th to early 20th centuries, which resulted in the widespread deposition of fine-grained and metal-rich waste throughout the Swale catchment. Additional fine sediment was sourced from gully erosion of headwater peats from the 18th century onwards. In the lower reaches of the Swale catchment, embankment construction during the late 18th century promoted the formation and preservation of agro-industrial alluvium units within the inter-embankment zone. Land-use change, particularly monastic deforestation in headwater tributaries of the River Swale during the 11th to 14th centuries, primed the uplands for widespread channel incision and sediment transfer and storage during the climatic deterioration of the ‘Little Ice Age’.

Agro-industrial alluvium is both sedimentologically and geochemically distinctive and constitutes a marker unit for historical human impact in the Swale catchment and similarly mining-affected river systems (Macklin et al., 1992a, 1997) in the UK. We suggest that in relation to recent discussion concerning the Anthropocene and its stratigraphic definition (Zalasiewicz et al., 2011), these sediments constitute a chronological marker within many catchments of the UK and Ireland impacted by historical metal mining. Similar types of metal-contaminated deposits have also been recorded in some urban catchments (e.g. River Aire, Leeds (Dawson and Macklin, 1998; Hudson-Edwards et al., 1999a)) that experienced early industrialisation. Based on sedimentological and geochemical analysis the ‘Anthropocene syndrome’ (cf. Meybeck, 2003) began in the Swale catchment at c. ad 1750, consistent with recently suggested dates for the start of the Anthropocene in the late 18th to early 19th centuries (Crutzen and Steffen, 2003; Zalasiewicz et al., 2011). Globally, alluvial deposits may well provide one of the most extensive and complete of records of the Anthropocene, particularly in catchments where large-scale mining occurred or where changes in agricultural land use and farming practices have taken place very rapidly (Brierley et al., 2005; Knox, 1972).
